content.full_text: Theodore L. McEvers or Abraham Lincoln to William E. McEvers, 11 July 18581 I Receiv2ed your letter of the SecindI was mutch pleazed to heare3from you the note of ad fers was never reternd to meI did not take a receipt for itI left it with a young man by the naim of Broadwel4he told me that he would hand it to mrlinconI a memarandom of the notethe note was for 249 00 dollars on 6 per cent you many concider your self duley autherized to dwo what you think best and you will mutch oblige your friend5
paragraphs: Theodore L. McEvers or Abraham Lincoln to William E.

McEvers, 11 July 18581 I Receiv2ed your letter of the SecindI was mutch pleazed to heare3from you the note of ad fers was never reternd to meI did not take a receipt for itI left it with a young man by the naim of Broadwel4he told me that he would hand it to mrlinconI a memarandom of the notethe note was for 249 00 dollars on 6 per cent you many concider your self duley autherized to dwo what you think best and you will mutch oblige your friend5

footnotes.text:
1Theodore L. McEvers wrote and signed this letter. He also wrote the names and addresses
                  on the envelope shown in the second image.
3“r” is written over a slightly erased “h”

5No correspondence between Abraham Lincoln and either Theodore L. McEvers or William
                  E. McEvers has been located. The topic of this letter and the context surrounding
                  it are, therefore, unclear.

6Lincoln wrote this docketing in pencil vertically on the right side of the envelope
                  shown in the second image.Mrs. Shearer could not be positively identified. No correspondence between Lincoln
                  and a Mrs. Shearer has been located.
